properties.chapter: Chapter 1: Introduction: Ibrahim Sultan in Battle
properties.description:
This folio from the Ibrahim Sultan Shahnama is from the preface of the manuscript. Many great patrons of the arts would have their likeness recreated within important text to have their glory and deeds enshrined for future readers. Ibrahim Sultan is no exception. The commissioning of a Shahnama was not only called for the greatness of the stories, but to emphasize the monarchs idealized activities such as hunting, feasting, consulting, excersizing justice and warfare (Abdullaeva, Melville. 2008, 42). 

 The folio here is a chaotic battle scene that can be divided into three sectors. These being, Ibrahim Sultan leading his troops into battle, the large battle scene in the lower half, depicting the two clashing sides on horseback, wielding swords and bows. Lastly the other contingance of troops behind the hillside on the top right of the folio.

Ibrahim Sultan, the grandson of Timur, was an accomplished governor, patron of the arts and calligrapher in Iran during his lifetime. Ibrahim, under his father, governored the area of Farz in Iran, where he was resopnsible for sponsoring many great works, including a Quran and Shahnama. Here we see a likely depiction of Ibrahim Sultan on horseback, wearing purple outfit, his horse dressed in golden armour, as he prepares to lead his troops into battle. It is unknown if this is a depiction of an actual battle in which Ibrahim Sultan took part in. In his lifetime he is known to have taken part in three battles, these being, Azerbaijan (823 AH, 1421 AD), Nakhchivan(824 AH, 1421 AD) and Khuzestan (825 AH, 1422 AD). This folio is likely enspired by one of these battles(Mirza-Abolqasemi 2019, 975). 

 Although not clearly identified, Ibrahim Sultan is mot likely to be the character centred in the folio. This characters posture, heading towatds the battle while also addressing the other soldiers, exemplifies his combat ability and leadership quality. This image is truly set out to glorify his rule and character.

Stationed behind Ibrahim Sultan in the top left of the image are mounted soldiers, who seem to be listening to the last instructions being placed upon them by Ibrahim Sultan before they enter the fray of battle. These characters all bear black scarves, and some as well have golden helmets as part of their armour. Each soldier, mounting a horse, which are covered in many different colours of armour. We see a horse covered in blue armour in the front row, seemingly looking out to the image's audience. One of the men on horseback, dressed in a light purple costume, listens intently to the words of Ibrahim Sultan. 

 Ibrahim Sultan was noted for not only being a great patron of the arts but a skilled warrior as well (Mirza-Abolqasemi 2019, 975). This image gives the impression that he was a brave warrior. He is most likely commanding his most skilled warriors into battle, rousing them with a speech.
"...and from the Insane Asylum on the southwest... "

"...to the Cemeteries on the northwest. Every foot of the vast territory within these limits has been carefully examined and topographically drawn in perspective, by Mr. C. N. Dry and his assistants, and the faithfulness and accuracy with which this work has been done an examination of the pages will attest. Absolute truth and accuracy in the representation of the territory has been the standard and in no cases have additions or alterations been made unless the same were actually in course of construction. In a few cases, important public and private edifices that are not yet finished are shown completed, and as they will appear when done. All the buildings within the limits of the survey in July, 1875, are shown; and a very large number of those executed or commenced since that date have been also introduced, the pages having been constantly corrected up to the last possible moment before publication."

"In dividing the work into pages, it will be seen that in, cases where a building is but partially drawn on one page, it is given complete on the adjoining page. In view of the magnitude of the work, the originality of the idea, and the difficulties encountered in carrying it out, it is hoped that if any mistakes or errors have crept into the plates or pages, they will be looked upon with a lenient eye by an indulgent public." (Dry & Compton)
